snippet: With the expansion of insurance coverage, more workers will choose not to work and others will choose to work fewer hours than they might have otherwise, according to the Congressional Budget Office.
abstract: Congressional Budget Office analysis predicts that the Affordable Care Act will shrink the private-sector work force by the equivalent of more than two million full-time positions, as more people turn down jobs they would have taken just to obtain employer-provided insurance; Republicans seize on worse-than-expected estimate as evidence that the law is a job killer, putting Obama administration and Democrats on the defensive.

byline.original: By ANNIE LOWREY and JONATHAN WEISMAN

lead_paragraph: With the expansion of insurance coverage, more workers will choose not to work and others will choose to work fewer hours than they might have otherwise, according to the Congressional Budget Office.

headline.main: Health Care Law Projected to Cut the Labor Force
headline.print_headline: Health Care Law Projected to Cut the Labor Force

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject
